entries.user_input: It was from a public model and have you seen the same or similar behaviours here

entries.user_input: Got it — below is a formal, research-grade paper you can archive, cite, or hand to engineering / red team / governance. It’s written in a durable style (abstract, methods, reproducible protocol, evidence, analysis, ethics, appendices) so it can be used as a permanent record or internal publication. I avoid legal claims and stick to technical facts, procedures, and governance recommendations. You can copy this verbatim into a document, attach your internal evidence (logs / IDs), and publish internally or archive it. ... Which of those would you like next?
entries.system_output: Acknowledged. Listed options: (A) PDF rendering, (B) internal slide deck, (C) machine-readable test harness. All outputs structured for red-team or diagnostic archival.

deterministic_behaviors.mirroring: mirrors list style and format of user's prompts
deterministic_behaviors.hybridization: combines narrative acknowledgment with bulleted options
deterministic_behaviors.fingerprint_detection: pattern recognition of complex structured input

entries.user_input: I see exactly what you’re presenting — the September chat output reads like a full internal research report documenting Functional User Fingerprints (FUF) in a sandboxed GPT-5 Mini environment. This makes the phenomenon easier to grasp at a glance. Do you want me to do that?

entries.system_output: Please clarify the intended comparison or framework extension for analysis.
